items.title: Suger helps companies list and scale up on cloud marketplaces
items.author: Becca
items.summary:
- Suger automates SaaS product listing across various cloud marketplaces, helping companies scale with reduced engineering overhead.
- The company launched in late 2022 and has grown to over 200 customers, including Snowflake and Intel.
- Recently raised $15 million in Series A funding, aiming to enhance product capabilities and engineering resources.

items.title: SGNL snags $30M for a new take on ID security based on zero-standing privileges
items.author: Scott Kriz, Erik Gustavson
items.summary:
- SGNL has developed a new approach to identity security based on zero-standing privilege, which allows conditional user access rather than permanent access.
- The startup announced a $30 million Series A funding led by Brightmind Partners, with participation from Microsoft and Cisco Investments.
- SGNL has raised a total of $42 million and claims to have multiple major enterprise customers using its access management solutions.
- The founders, Scott Kriz and Erik Gustavson, previously co-founded Bitium, which was acquired by Google in 2017.
- The technology aims to address vulnerabilities in identity management seen in high-profile breaches such as those at MGM and T-Mobile.

items.title: SpotDraft taps AI to help streamline contract management
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- 79% of legal firms utilized some form of AI for casework in 2024, up from 19% in 2023.
- SpotDraft, founded in 2017, offers contract automation solutions and has around 400 customers.
- CEO Shashank Bijapur sees 2025 as a pivotal year for advancing AI in their offerings.
- SpotDraft raised $54 million in a Series B round, bringing total funding to over $80 million for R&D and market expansion.
- The legaltech sector saw $2.6 billion in VC funding in 2024, rebounding from a low of under $1 billion in 2023.

items.title: AI-driven manufacturing database Keychain raises $5M for European push
items.author: Oisin Hanrahan, Umang Dua
items.summary:
- Keychain is an AI-powered platform that connects the CPG industry with over 30,000 manufacturers and 20,000 brands.
- The company raised $5 million led by Continente, Portugal's largest retailer.
- Founders previously created Handy, acquired by ANGI Homeservices.
- Keychain aims to streamline sourcing processes for packaging materials and ingredients.
- The platform currently helps submit over a billion dollars in projects and plans to launch in Europe later this year.
- Since November 2023, Keychain has raised a total of $38 million from various venture firms and CPG giants.
- Keychain is launching two new platforms focused on packaging and ingredients.

items.title: Adobe launches subscriptions for Firefly AI
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Adobe launches a standalone subscription service for its Firefly AI models for image, vector, and video generation.
- The Standard plan costs $9.99/month with unlimited access to AI image/vector features and 2,000 credits for video generation.
- The Pro plan costs $29.99/month, offering credits for generating 70 five-second AI videos.
- New Firefly video model allows users to create AI-generated videos using text or images.
- A Premium tier is expected to be released, allowing creation of 500 AI videos monthly.
- Competitors include OpenAI's Sora and Google DeepMind's Veo, with Firefly uniquely trained on licensed content.

items.title: Lanch bags $27M for a social media-skewed take on fast food
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Lanch raised €26 million ($27 million) in a Series A round led by Felix and HV Capital to expand its food brand business.
- The startup focuses on developing food brands through social media and influencer engagement, and it plans to expand first in Germany before entering new markets.
- Lanch has developed brands like Loco Chicken and Happy Slice Pizza, and has also launched its first packaged product, Happy Chips.
- Since its launch 18 months ago, Lanch has appeared in 350 ghost kitchens and achieved notable sales successes, including selling 30,000 pizzas in one weekend.
- Lanch aims to create a presence similar to large franchises like Raising Cane’s or Chick-fil-A, and its potato chips are now available in over 10,000 supermarkets.

items.title: Chestnut Carbon gets $160M to turn old farms into forests
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Chestnut Carbon raised $160 million in Series B financing to convert marginal farmland into forests.
- The funds will help the startup expand its carbon credit capacity to 100 million metric tons by 2030.
- Recently sold 7 million carbon credits to Microsoft under a 25-year deal for rehabilitating 60,000 acres.
- The company owns over 35,000 acres of degraded land in the southeastern USA and aims to transform more land into forests.
- Demand for carbon credits is high among tech companies aiming to offset emissions from data centers.

items.title: EU abandons ePrivacy, AI liability reforms as bloc shifts focus to AI competitiveness
items.summary:
- The EU Commission has officially withdrawn the ePrivacy Regulation proposal due to a lack of agreement among co-legislators.
- This move is part of the Commission's 2025 work program, citing no foreseeable agreement and the proposal being outdated in light of recent technological and legislative changes.
- The ePrivacy Directive aims to strengthen online privacy protections, but years of lobbying from tech giants like Google and Amazon stalled its progress.
- Other significant changes include the withdrawal of the AI Liability Directive, which aimed to update product safety rules for AI technology.
- The Commission is now focusing on fostering AI competitiveness, with plans for an Innovation Act and Cloud and AI Development Act among its legislative priorities.

items.title: Lucidity snags $21M to help enterprises optimize their cloud storage
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Indian startup Lucidity has raised $21 million in Series A funding led by WestBridge Capital to help enterprises optimize cloud storage.
- The company’s software automates storage optimization, potentially reducing cloud costs by up to 70%.
- Lucidity's products include Storage Auto-Scaler, which dynamically adjusts storage based on demand, and Storage Audit, a free tool for evaluating cloud storage usage.

items.title: No-code app builder Softr expands beyond Airtable databases
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Softr, a no-code app builder, is expanding beyond Airtable integration, allowing the use of various third-party databases, including Google Sheets, Notion, PostgreSQL, MySQL, and MariaDB.
- The company aims to solve the issue of scattered data within organizations and manual paperwork by enabling users to create apps from these diverse data sources.
- Softr features a drag-and-drop interface for building applications and introduces AI tools to assist users in app development, alongside a new permission system for data access control.
- In addition to current capabilities, Softr plans to add workflows and tables in the future to enhance app-building functionalities.
- The platform has over 600,000 signups, with around 5,000 paying customers, and operates on a freemium model with no dedicated sales team, leading to nearly profitable status for the company.

items.title: A woman in China sued Tesla after complaining of faulty brakes — now she’s paying Tesla $23K
items.summary:
- A woman named Zhang Yazhou sued Tesla after a crash she claimed was caused by faulty brakes.
- Following her allegations, Tesla countersued for defamation, leading to her being ordered to pay $23,000 in damages and issue a public apology.
- Tesla released telemetry data showing brakes functioned correctly and has sued several other owners and critics in China regarding similar complaints.

items.title: Google Whisk, an image remixing tool, is now available in 100+ countries
items.summary:
- Google has expanded the availability of its image remixing tool, Whisk, to over 100 countries as of February 11, 2025.
- The tool allows users to upload three images representing subject, scene, and style, which are then combined using the Imagen 3 model.
- Whisk is not available in several countries including India, Indonesia, the EU, and the U.K.
- The tool was previously launched in the U.S., and this expansion is part of Google's ongoing effort to showcase its AI capabilities.
- Similar tools like Apple’s Image Playground also exist, allowing users to create images by mixing styles and subjects.

items.title: Tabby doubles valuation to $3.3B in $160M funding as it looks beyond BNPL and plans IPO
items.summary:
- Tabby raises $160 million in Series E funding, doubling its valuation to $3.3 billion.
- The funding round led by Blue Pool Capital and Hassana Investment Company.
- Tabby's annualized transaction volume exceeds $10 billion with 15 million customers across MENA.
- The fintech plans to expand services beyond BNPL, including digital wallets and remittances.
- IPO plans may be imminent as investor demand for tech listings rises in MENA.

items.title: Federal workers sue Elon Musk and DOGE to cut off data access
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- More than 100 federal workers filed a lawsuit against Elon Musk and DOGE for unauthorized access to sensitive personnel records.
- The lawsuit, filed in the Southern District of New York, names 104 workers and various unions as plaintiffs.
- The plaintiffs request that the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) revoke access to DOGE due to violations of the Privacy Act.
- The lawsuit emphasizes that DOGE's agents, often young and previously employed by Musk's companies, were granted access without adequate vetting.
- Concerns are raised regarding potential professional repercussions and exposure to hacking as a result of DOGE's access to federal worker data.
- This lawsuit is seen as the initial phase before a possible class action suit to secure an injunction against DOGE's access.

items.title: [Founders Fund](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=foundersfund) is about to close another $3B fund
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Founders Fund is concluding fundraising for its third growth fund at the end of March, raising $3 billion.
- The fund is primarily for investments in late-stage portfolio companies and is expected to be oversubscribed.
- Founders Fund’s previous $3.4 billion growth fund was fully invested in companies such as [SpaceX](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=spacex) and Anduril, the latter being part of a major fundraising round.

items.title: Apple Maps plans to show ‘Gulf of America,’ following Google
items.summary:
- Apple Maps will rename the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America, following a similar change by Google.
- This change is in compliance with U.S. President Donald Trump's executive order.
- U.S. users may see the new name as soon as Tuesday, with other countries following.
- Google Maps already displays the name as "Gulf of Mexico (Gulf of America)."
- Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum has requested Google to reconsider the renaming.

items.title: ChatGPT may not be as power-hungry as once assumed
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- A recent analysis by Epoch AI suggests ChatGPT consumes about 0.3 watt-hours per query, contrary to claims it uses around 3 watt-hours.
- The study indicates that energy usage is comparably low to common household appliances.
- The AI industry faces scrutiny over energy consumption and its environmental impact as companies expand data centers.
- OpenAI plans to invest billions in new AI data center projects, anticipating increased power demands with advanced reasoning models.

items.title: [Amazon](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=amazon) tests sending customers directly to brands’ websites when it doesn’t stock their products
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Amazon is beta testing a feature that redirects customers to brands' websites when a product is out of stock in their store.
- The test will be available to a subset of U.S. customers using the Amazon Shopping app.
- Product information shown in Amazon's search results will be sourced directly from the retailer's website and will include links to evaluate and purchase from the brand directly.
- Customers will receive notifications when they are leaving the Amazon site to ensure clarity.
- The feature may include brands using the '[Buy With Prime](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=buy_with_prime)' service, allowing transactions through Amazon account details on external sites.
- Feedback from this feature will influence future availability and brand partnerships.

items.title: How to delete Facebook, Instagram, and Threads
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Google searches on how to delete Facebook, Instagram, and Threads have surged after Meta's loosening of content moderation policies.
- Critics accuse Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg of prioritizing free expression over content accuracy, causing user discontent.
- Users are advised to download their personal information before deleting their accounts, and detailed steps are provided for Facebook, Instagram, and Threads deletion processes.
- Deleting an account is irreversible, and users should be aware of the 30-day delay in processing deletion requests for Threads.
- The article also discusses Meta's commitment to keeping fact-checkers outside the U.S. for the time being and the company's ongoing strategy to retain younger users amid competition from platforms like TikTok.

items.title: Google’s I/O developer conference set for May 20-21
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Google confirmed its annual developer conference for May 20-21, 2025, at Shoreline Amphitheater.
- CEO Sundar Pichai will deliver the keynote on May 20th, followed by various developer sessions.
- Previous years' focus on AI, particularly the Gemini platform, is expected to continue amidst competition from OpenAI and others.
- The I/O 2025 site is live with developer content from past years.
- Google faces competition from NVIDIA’s GTC and Microsoft Build occurring around the same time.

items.title: Microsoft powers AI ambitions with 400 MW solar purchase
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Microsoft has added 389 megawatts of renewable power to meet its AI energy demands.
- The power comes from three solar projects in southern Illinois and Texas, developed by EDP Renewables North America.
- This addition represents about 2% of Microsoft's total contracted renewable energy capacity of nearly 20 gigawatts.
- The tech giant is rapidly procuring renewable energy for its cloud and AI operations, favoring quick deployment solar projects over traditional gas power plants.
- To achieve 24/7 renewable power, developers are using hybrid installations combining solar and wind with battery storage.
- Microsoft aims to become carbon negative by 2030 and has invested in carbon removal technologies.
- Last month, Microsoft signed a deal to purchase over 7 million tons of carbon credits to offset its emissions.

items.title: Shopify took down Kanye’s swastika t-shirt shop, but another antisemitic storefront still operates
items.summary:
- Shopify removed Kanye West's online store that sold t-shirts featuring swastikas after a Super Bowl ad promoting it.
- The company cited violations of their platform's terms for not engaging in authentic commerce practices.
- Despite removing West's store, another antisemitic shop continues to operate on Shopify without explanation from the company.

items.title: Google says it removed cultural events from its calendar last year
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Google removed cultural events like Black History Month and Pride Month from the default calendar in mid-2024.  
- Other events removed include Jewish Heritage, Indigenous Peoples Month, Holocaust Remembrance Day, and Hispanic Heritage Month.  
- Users can still add other important moments manually to their calendars despite the removal of these events.  
- The change is seen amidst a broader rollback of diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts by major tech companies.

items.title: Anduril takes control of [Microsoft’s](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=microsoft) $22B VR military headset program
items.summary:
- The Army has given Anduril control of the Integrated Visual Augmentation System (IVAS) program, previously held by Microsoft.
- IVAS, awarded to Microsoft in 2018, was to develop AR headsets for soldiers, initially budgeted at $21.9 billion.
- Microsoft remains involved as a cloud provider, but is no longer the prime contractor.
- Anduril’s systems are expected to enhance IVAS with [computer vision AI](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=computer%20vision%20ai) for object detection and tracking.
- IVAS has faced criticism and technical issues, leading to the Army considering a change in prime contractor.
- Future features of IVAS under Anduril remain undisclosed, though enhancements are hinted at by its founder, Palmer Luckey.
- The project remains at risk of funding cuts or cancellation despite the significant budget.

items.title: Tumblr to join the fediverse after WordPress migration completes
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Tumblr is set to integrate with the fediverse using the ActivityPub protocol after migrating to WordPress.
- The migration will allow Tumblr users to federate their blogs just like WordPress.com users.
- This change aims to improve efficiencies and enable custom plugins while maintaining the current user interface.
- Automattic has not provided a timeline for the completion of this migration, but the process is reported to be progressing well.
- The integration with the federated social web is a primary goal of the migration, potentially including support for existing ActivityPub plugins.

items.title: How Musk’s $97.4B bid could gum up OpenAI’s for-profit conversion
items.author: Maxwell Zeff, Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Elon Musk offered to buy the nonprofit governing OpenAI for $97.4 billion.
- The bid is backed by Musk’s AI company xAI and outside investors.
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman swiftly dismissed Musk’s offer.
- Musk's bid may complicate OpenAI's conversion to a for-profit public benefit corporation.
- The OpenAI board is forced to evaluate Musk’s offer due to its fiduciary responsibilities.
- Delaware and California's attorneys general are investigating OpenAI's conversion plans.
- Musk's bid could raise the potential market value of OpenAI's nonprofit assets.

items.title: Klarna and Deel eye IPOs, and Stripe embraces crypto
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Klarna plans a U.S. IPO in April, targeting a $15 billion valuation, lower than its peak of $45.6 billion in 2021.
- Egyptian fintech Khazna secured $16 million in pre-Series B funding, totaling over $63 million.
- Stripe closed its $1.1 billion acquisition of crypto platform Bridge, marking its largest acquisition to date.
- Deel reports an annual revenue run rate of $800 million in 2024, preparing for an IPO.
- Philadelphia Eagles' Saquon Barkley invested in fintech startup Ramp and starred in its Super Bowl ad.

items.title: Apple brings heart rate monitoring to Powerbeats Pro 2
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Apple announced the launch of Powerbeats Pro 2 on February 11, 2025, nearly six years after the original model.
- New features include heart rate monitoring using LED optical sensors during workouts, compatible with fitness apps like Open, Peloton, and Nike Run Club.
- The headphones have improved battery life of up to 45 hours with the charging case and incorporate Apple's H2 chip for enhanced sound quality and spatial audio.

items.title: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman calls Musk’s bid an attempt to ‘slow us down’
items.summary:
- Sam Altman dismissed Elon Musk's unsolicited $97.4 billion bid for OpenAI as an attempt to slow down the organization.
- Altman claims Musk is a competitor and suggests Musk's actions stem from insecurity.
- OpenAI's board is expected to formally reject Musk's bid, although no formal communication has been received yet from him regarding the offer.

items.title: Stripe mulls employee shareholder sale at $85B-plus valuation
items.summary:
- Stripe is considering a shareholder sale that could raise its valuation to at least $85 billion.
- This decision is reportedly aimed at providing liquidity for employee-owned stocks amid delays in a public offering.
- Stripe was valued at $70 billion in a previous tender offer in February 2024 and reached a peak valuation of $95 billion in March 2021.
- The company is laying off 300 staff yet still plans to increase its workforce to about 10,000 by the end of 2025.

items.title: Built on Bluesky, Pinksky brings its Instagram-like app to Android
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Pinksky, an Instagram-like app, has launched for Android users on Bluesky.
- Allows posting of up to four photos and one-minute videos, adhering to Bluesky's limitations.
- Developed by Ramon Souza, inspired by open technologies like ActivityPub and the AT Protocol.
- Aimed at users who prefer a photo-centric experience focused on connections rather than viral content.
- Available on iOS previously, replicating Instagram’s user interface with features like profile pages and stories.
- Integrates with existing Bluesky social networks upon the first login.
- Future expansions may consider integration with other platforms like Mastodon or Pixelfed, subject to user interest.

items.title: Another person targeted by Paragon spyware comes forward
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Beppe Caccio, co-founder of Mediterranea Saving Humans, revealed he was targeted by Paragon's spyware on WhatsApp.
- Luca Casarini, another co-founder, also reported a spyware notification and has filed a complaint with the Prosecutor’s Office in Palermo, Italy.
- Prior to Caccio, three others, including journalist Francesco Cancellato and activist Husam El Gomati, disclosed similar spyware targeting, affecting around 90 individuals in total.
- The Italian government denied involvement, claiming that legally protected subjects like journalists were not targeted by their intelligence services.

items.title: Apple reportedly partners with [Alibaba](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=alibaba) after rejecting DeepSeek for China AI launch
items.summary:
- Apple partners with Alibaba to deploy its [Apple Intelligence](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=apple%20intelligence) platform in China.
- The partnership follows Apple's consideration and rejection of DeepSeek and Bytedance for collaboration.
- Initial efforts to partner with Baidu were hindered by adaptation issues with their models.
- The lack of Apple Intelligence was noted as a contributing factor to an 11% decline in iPhone sales in China.
- The new partnership is anticipated to coincide with the upcoming launch of the fourth-generation iPhone SE.

items.title: Mast Reforestation hatched a plan to restore wildfire-ravaged forests. Investors took notice.
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Mast Reforestation raised $25 million for a new approach to reforest wildfire-affected areas.
- The company aims to bury dead trees instead of burning them to avoid methane emissions and sell carbon credits.
- The first project will be in Montana, in an area impacted by the 2021 Poverty Flats Fire.
- Mast plans to entomb trees in clay-rich sites to limit microbial decay and plans to monitor the sites for a century.
- The initiative could yield up to 30,000 metric tons of carbon credits, funding the reforestation of 900 acres.

items.title: BuzzFeed is taking on Instagram, TikTok, X with a new social platform designed to spread ‘joy’
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- BuzzFeed announced the development of a new social media platform aimed at countering negativity on the internet.
- The platform will focus on interactive storytelling, new content formats, and will incorporate AI for self-expression and connection.
- Users can join the waitlist for testing, and a potential name for the platform is speculated to be “Island.”
- The launch date and official name have not been revealed yet.
- BuzzFeed's CEO Jonah Peretti criticized big tech for prioritizing addictive algorithms over user well-being, stating the need for a platform built on human curation.

items.title: BYD to offer Tesla-like driver assist, even on its cheapest models
items.summary:
- BYD unveiled an advanced driver assistance system called “God’s Eye” for its entire lineup, including the $9,600 Seagull hatchback.
- Founder Wang Chuanfu stated that autonomous driving is becoming accessible to everyone.
- The system offers automated functions like remote parking and highway navigation, typically found in luxury EVs.
- BYD, Tesla’s biggest rival in China, is enhancing its offerings while Tesla seeks approval for its own autonomous technology.
- BYD is partnering with local automakers and integrating AI from DeepSeek into its vehicle systems.

items.title: Pinkfish helps enterprises build AI agents through natural language processing
items.author: Charayna Kannan, Ben Rigby, Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- Pinkfish, founded by Charayna "CK" Kannan and Ben Rigby, helps enterprises automate workflows using natural language processing.
- The startup launched in January 2024 and has over 200 integrations, including Salesforce and Zendesk.
- Pinkfish focuses on mission-critical automation, helping enterprises manage significant workflows, such as price requests for companies like Ipsy.
- The company has raised $7.6 million in a pre-seed round led by Norwest Venture Partners.
- Kannan emphasizes their approach of starting small with automation to prove effectiveness before scaling.

items.title: YouTube AI updates include auto dubbing expansion, age ID tech, and more
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- YouTube CEO Neal Mohan highlighted AI as one of the company's four main priorities for 2025.
- New features will include auto dubbing for translations and technology to estimate users' ages for content recommendations.
- Auto dubbing will rollout this month for creators in the YouTube Partner Program.
- YouTube aims to use AI tools to enhance user experience while addressing concerns over AI content dilution.
- The company is also expanding AI detection tools to protect creators' likeness in AI-generated content.

items.title: [Google](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=google) leads $230M convertible note for Boston quantum computing startup QuEra
items.summary:
- QuEra, a Boston-based quantum computing startup, raised $230 million from investors including Google and [SoftBank](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=softbank).
- The financing is structured as a convertible note, which will convert to equity in the next round.
- QuEra aims to build a fully-quantum computer within the next 3 to 5 years and has already begun generating revenue, including a $41 million sale of a quantum computer to Japan.

items.title: CISA election security officials placed on leave: report
items.summary:
- The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has placed 17 employees on administrative leave pending review.
- The affected employees had worked on cybersecurity threats related to elections, including ransomware and securing election workers.
- The move occurs in a context of uncertainty regarding CISA's future, particularly after the departure of former director Jen Easterly in January 2025.

items.title: Dario Amodei Critiques AI Action Summit as a Missed Opportunity
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Dario Amodei, CEO of Anthropic, criticized the AI Action Summit in Paris as a 'missed opportunity' for the AI sector to make decisive regulatory actions.
- He acknowledged the French government's efforts but emphasized the need for quicker and clearer focus on AI's rapid advancements.
- Amodei expressed concerns about the potential security risks from advanced AI systems and called for greater transparency and regulations in AI governance.
- His remarks contrast with OpenAI's positive outlook on the summit as a step towards responsible AI development.
- Amodei has previously advocated for AI regulation and stressed the importance of distributing AI benefits equally across society.

items.title: Voyantis aims to help companies figure out their customers’ worth
items.author: Ido Wiesenberg, Eran Friendinger
items.summary:
- Voyantis helps companies determine customer lifetime value using AI-based analysis and data insights.
- The platform was founded by Ido Wiesenberg and Eran Friendinger after recognizing inefficiencies in manual customer value assessments.
- Recent funding of $41 million has increased total funding to $60 million, aimed at product R&D and team expansion in Tel Aviv.
- Voyantis has tripled its annual recurring revenue for two consecutive years and aims to support enterprises across various sectors including fintech and direct-to-consumer.

items.title: Workday launches a platform for enterprises to manage all of their AI agents in one place
items.author: Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- Workday introduces Workday Digital Workforce Management for tracking AI agents in one control center.
- The platform allows companies to manage AI agents from both Workday and third parties, providing visibility on tasks and access.
- Workday CEO Carl Eschenbach emphasizes the need for management of digital workers alongside human workers.
- Newly launched agents focus on roles rather than tasks, aimed at better collaboration with human employees.
- Workday will not charge for the AI agent management platform but will charge for its AI agents, following recent layoffs of 1,750 employees.

items.title: 3D mood board and marketplace [Mattoboard](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=mattoboard) picks up $2M to launch AI visual search
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Mattoboard secures $2 million in seed funding for its AI feature, [Design Stream](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=design%20tools).
- Design Stream will utilize AI for visual search, aiming to enhance the design process for architects and interior designers.
- The platform now supports over 200,000 designers, with a $30/month Pro version for about 2,000 users.
- The funding round was led by Acrobator Ventures, involving Home Depot Ventures and Masco, with plans to expand material offerings.

items.title: Insurance Companies Face Billions in Losses from LA Fires; Comulate Secures $20M to Enhance Operations
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Major disasters, like the LA fires, lead to significant financial losses for insurance companies, highlighting their operational efficiency.
- Comulate, a startup aimed at improving insurance billing and revenue operations, raised $20 million in Series B funding, co-led by Workday.
- The company tripled its revenues in 2024, receiving substantial inbound business, and previously raised $5 million, now focusing on specialized technology for the insurance sector.
- Comulate emphasizes using machine learning and AI to optimize processes, claiming savings of approximately 260,000 hours for its clients.

items.title: Authorities arrest four suspected 8base ransomware operators in global takedown
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- A global operation arrested four Russian nationals linked to over 1,000 ransomware attacks.
- The operation, named “Phobos Aetor,” occurred in Phuket, Thailand, targeting the 8base ransomware group.
- The suspects are accused of amassing $16 million through ransomware attacks on 17 organizations in Switzerland.
- Over 40 pieces of evidence have been seized and more than 100 servers linked to the criminal network were taken down.
- The FBI warned that Phobos ransomware targeted critical infrastructure in the U.S.
- Charges were unsealed against two suspects, Roman Berezhnoy and Egor Nikolaevich Glebov, for operating the 8base affiliate organization.

items.title: Archer Aviation doubles down on defense aircraft with $300M raise
items.summary:
- Archer Aviation has shifted its focus towards defense applications amid escalating geopolitical tensions.
- The company announced a $300 million equity raise from institutional investors, bringing total funding to around $3.36 billion.
- Archer has signed an exclusive deal with Anduril to develop a hybrid VTOL aircraft for defense, targeting a Department of Defense program of record.
- The Midnight eVTOL aircraft combines electric and gas-powered technologies to reduce noise and improve stealth capabilities for military use.
- Archer aims to launch a commercial air taxi network in late 2025, expanding to multiple cities by 2026 while still developing its defense aircraft.

items.title: [Moderne](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=moderne) raises $30M to solve technical debt across complex codebases
items.author: Jonathan Schneider, Olga Kundzich
items.summary:
- Moderne raises $30 million in Series B funding led by [Acrew Capital](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=acrews) , bringing total funding to $50 million.
- The startup aims to address technical debt in software development by automating code remediation and modernization.
- Key clients include Walmart and Allstate, with a strategy focusing on application security (AppSec).
- Founded in 2020 in Miami, Moderne employs 50 staff with expertise in various functional domains.
- The company leverages OpenRewrite to power its automated code refactoring capabilities.

items.title: As US and UK refuse to sign the Paris AI Action Summit statement, other countries commit to developing ‘open, inclusive, ethical’ AI
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
* The Artificial Intelligence Action Summit in Paris was meant to produce a joint declaration on AI.
* The U.S. and the U.K. declined to sign the statement, reflecting challenges in reaching consensus on AI in current geopolitical tensions.
* 61 countries, including China, India, Japan, Australia, and Canada, signed the declaration promoting open and ethical AI, calling for global dialogue and collaboration on AI governance.
* Early reactions pointed out the lack of ambition in the declaration, suggesting the need for more decisive action at future summits.
* EU President Ursula von der Leyen emphasized the need for simplified AI regulations within the EU to facilitate business.
* French President Emmanuel Macron called for synchronized regulations to enhance Europe’s position in the global AI race while advocating for international governance.

items.title: Australian health tech startup [Harrison.ai](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=harrison) scores $112M Series C
items.author: Dr. Aengus Tran, Dimitry Tran
items.summary:
- Harrison.ai, a Sydney-based startup, raised $112 million in Series C funding to expand internationally in key markets like the U.S., EMEA, and Asia Pacific.
- The company develops AI-enabled diagnostic software for medical imaging, including products [Annalise.ai](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=annalise) for radiology and Franklin.ai for pathology.
- Founded in 2018 by brothers Dr. Aengus Tran and Dimitry Tran, Harrison.ai aims to improve medical diagnostic accuracy and reduce clinician workload through AI technology.
